Sansa: no don’t be mean!
Rickon, swinging Shaggydog back and forth: stinky bastard...
body:
Rickon, holding up baby Shaggydog: Stinky!

Sansa: no don’t be mean!

Rickon, swinging Shaggydog back and forth: stinky bastard man!

Sansa: no!!!!!!

Arya, not looking up from playing with Nymeria: naughty boy, brat direwolf

Sansa, distraught: NOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!!

summary: Watching Daenerys throughout season one is so utterly heartbreaking. There's this sweet, innocent child, that spent her whole...
body:
Watching Daenerys throughout season one is so utterly heartbreaking. There’s this sweet, innocent child, that spent her whole life in foreign lands with a monstrous brother that constantly abused her, and eventually sold her to a rapist like a broodmare; to be raped and abused by him for the rest of her life. And when she manages to find a way to command his respect and win him over, having spent her life completely unguided and lost, she genuinely mistakes her relationship with her abuser to be that of love. She clings to the power and protection Drogo can offer her, tricking herself into believing that she could love her rapist, and that he loves her too.

I truly love the antithesis between early Dany and Margaret Tyrell here. Margaery, growing up by the side of a woman as intelligent and savvy as Olenna, doesn’t let her emotions get the better of her for a second. She plays men, knowing perfectly well there are great things at stakes, but she isn’t foolish enough to fall for her own façade. She knows perfectly well that if she plays the game well she can gain a lot, but not a moment goes by when she sees, say, Joffrey as anything else than a means to an end, much less delude herself to see him as anything but the monster he is.

And, of course, there’s the contrast between the girl Dany is in season one and the woman she grows into. All the pain, all the bitter experiences and torture she’s been through shapes her into the strong woman she is now. Daenerys, much like Sansa, had to learn the hard way, but that’s what makes the capable and determined ruler she is, while never losing her empathy either.

— tracking #ladysansa

summary:
do you ever just think about how young all the main protagonists of GoT were in the books and they went through so much 
In the...
body:
do you ever just think about how young all the main protagonists of GoT were in the books and they went through so much

In the novel(s) I’m pretty sure like 2-3 years passes between all the novels but I could be wrong, please correct me if I am:

Daenerys: 13-15 (is abused by her brother, marries Khal Drogo (who is in his early 30s), is r*ped by him, and gives birth to Rhaego when she’s 14 (which is how old my mother was when she gave birth to my oldest brother) and it really is just gross @ GRRM what were you thinking. Is sexually assaulted by Jorah Mormont, a much older man, who she trusts and views as a friend, and much, much more)

Jon: 14-16 (his relationship w/Ygritte in the books really irks me considering she’s 17/18 and if the Jon were a woman and Ygritte were man it would be considered super sketch but whatever, takes on the job of Lord Commander when he’s like 16)

Robb: 14-16 (goes to war, kills men at 14 because of Joffrey betrayal of his father, has the burden of kingship places upon him, is around 16 when he dies)

Sansa: 11-13 (12(?) when she is forced to marry Tyrion, though he doesn’t force her to do anything (he still thinks about her sexually), is essentially groomed by LF, beaten and abused in front of the whole court, emotionally abused by Cersei, lives w/the guilt of having been forced by the Lannisters to essentially betray her father, has her beloved pet murdered for something she didn’t do, etc.)

Arya: 9-11 (witnessed her father being beheaded, is later turned into an assassin by a super shady group of people, has her friend murdered by the Lannisters, finds a family in Gendry only to have that taken away, is seperated from her family, etc.)

Bran: 7-9 (is pushed from a window and permenantly disabled, is forced from his home + separated from his family)

Rickon: 2-4 (forced to flee Winterfell because it’s taken over and is separated from his whole family)

Theon Greyjoy: 18/19(?)-20/21 (is castrated/tortured by Ramsay Bolton until he loses all sense of who he is)

Brienne of Tarth: 17-19 (witnesses the death of her king (who she is in love with), and is forced to take on various missions in a bid to fulfill her promise to Catelyn Stark)

Now I may be wrong by like a year or two for some of them but still. They’re all so young. Also I couldn’t list everything each other’s characters went though bc I’ve just began rereading the first book and I don’t remember that much from the series. If you have anything to add feel free because I no doubt missed quite a few things/if I got anything wrong.

do you ever just think about how young all the main protagonists of GoT were in the books and they went through so much

In the novel(s) I’m pretty sure like 2-3 years passes between all the novels but I could be wrong, please correct me if I am:

Daenerys: 13-15 (is abused by her brother, marries Khal Drogo (who is in his early 30s), is r*ped by him, and gives birth to Rhaego when she’s 14 (which is how old my mother was when she gave birth to my oldest brother) and it really is just gross @ GRRM what were you thinking. Is sexually assaulted by Jorah Mormont, a much older man, who she trusts and views as a friend, and much, much more)

Jon: 14-16 (his relationship w/Ygritte in the books really irks me considering she’s 17/18 and if the Jon were a woman and Ygritte were man it would be considered super sketch but whatever, takes on the job of Lord Commander when he’s like 16)

Robb: 14-16 (goes to war, kills men at 14 because of Joffrey betrayal of his father, has the burden of kingship places upon him, is around 16 when he dies)

Sansa: 11-13 (12(?) when she is forced to marry Tyrion, though he doesn’t force her to do anything (he still thinks about her sexually), is essentially groomed by LF, beaten and abused in front of the whole court, emotionally abused by Cersei, lives w/the guilt of having been forced by the Lannisters to essentially betray her father, has her beloved pet murdered for something she didn’t do, etc.)

Arya: 9-11 (witnessed her father being beheaded, is later turned into an assassin by a super shady group of people, has her friend murdered by the Lannisters, finds a family in Gendry only to have that taken away, is seperated from her family, etc.)

Bran: 7-9 (is pushed from a window and permenantly disabled, is forced from his home + separated from his family)

Rickon: 2-4 (forced to flee Winterfell because it’s taken over and is separated from his whole family)

Theon Greyjoy: 18/19(?)-20/21 (is castrated/tortured by Ramsay Bolton until he loses all sense of who he is)

Brienne of Tarth: 17-19 (witnesses the death of her king (who she is in love with), and is forced to take on various missions in a bid to fulfill her promise to Catelyn Stark)

Now I may be wrong by like a year or two for some of them but still. They’re all so young. Also I couldn’t list everything each other’s characters went though bc I’ve just began rereading the first book and I don’t remember that much from the series. If you have anything to add feel free because I no doubt missed quite a few things/if I got anything wrong.

blog.name: oddcoupler222
blog.title: a professional mess. jk i dont get paid for this
blog.description: haley. 27. antagonist in my own life. probably daydreaming too much about fictional characters. Multifandom trash but currently sansa stark fan above all else

tags: my sansaery love is rising all over again
thanks for being so damn beautiful and addictive

blog.name: fedonciadale
blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: 1)Just a confession, not a question. I get angry at j in the boatsex scene on behalf of S. I know it's not cheating but I get...
question: 1)Just a confession, not a question. I get angry at j in the boatsex scene on behalf of S. I know it's not cheating but I get mad coz I feel like he's wronging her. I skip that scene during my every rewatch. It reminded me of richonne from TWD, where they're going fine & then Jessie shows up. I was mad at Rick too though the situations are different. I feel like j should apologize to S, tell her he's always loved her & D was his way of getting over her but he couldn't, win her over & prove
answer:
2) prove himself worthy of her else I won’t be satisfied.

Dear nonny,

I must admit that I don’t feel like that. Maybe that is because I am a middle aged woman who knows that life and love can be complicated?

I mean it is all very romantic to think that there is this one person who is the ‘love of your life’ and if you just meet them, it will be all sunshine and rainbows, and easy.

It is not. I’m not saying there is not something like 'love of your life’ but a) the love of your life might just not work out. And b) there is also an element of choice in love, because of course we fall in love, but we still have choices. Imagine being married and maybe even happily married and then you meet someone who is a perfect fit and who is one of the few people in the world who could be the 'love of your life’. Then the important thing is what you choose to do. [Edit: And I think it is important that Jon and Sansa choose not to act on their feelings pre-parentage reveal]

A friend of mine is married to a man whose fiancee died in a car crash before he met her. If that car crash hadn’t happened he would have married the other woman and might not even have met my friend. Yet now they are happy. Does this devalidate his first love?

I mean I do not believe in Ned/Ashara because I think it was Brandon/ Ashara, but just imagine for a moment that Ned having a tryst with Ashara at the tourney of Harrenhal, when he did not know Cat and had no duty to her, would devalidate 15 years of a marriage - when they both put a lot of effort into the marriage?

Just imagine for a moment that Jon were indeed Ned’s son, and he decided to marry D for the good of the North, because he can’t have Sansa anyway. Imagine just for a moment that maybe D was not such a hypocrite and actually a nice woman. Would you begrudge Jon an attempt to become happy despite his ill fated love for his half sister? Or would you expect him to stay miserable for the rest of his life? I mean I think Jon and D are ultimately and completely unfitting for each other, and they are doomed whatever happens between Jon and Sansa, but just play with the scenario for a moment.

Now I have this of my chest: Jon does not owe the woman he thinks is his half sister any explanation of his sex life, even being madly in love with Sansa (as I think he is). What he does owe her and Arya and Bran and the NL is an explanation of why he bent the knee (or maybe not bent the knee). The North is not an absolutistic state and therefore an explanation is needed - and this explanation is difficult. Because Jon might be loathe to tell everyone that D is a great queen and this is why he bent the knee. Telling them D is a great queen might not work, they might see immediately that this is not the truth. But he also can’t tell that D kept him prisoner and that he played along because that would piss of Da€nerys. The woman has dragons and he has to let her believe that he came over because she is a amazeballs. So a public explanation in front of everybody is out of the question and Jon might decide to just stay silent on the matter - in the hope that the NL are not too angry or immediately suspect him of acting out of love.

Jon might even fear to give an explanation in private, because 'the best way to keep a secret is to tell nobody’. I don’t envy him.

Now after RLJ, the situation is different and if Jon and Sansa do indeed become a couple Jon should talk about his tryst with D. If Political Jon is true he has to explain and he might tell Sansa that he only ever loved her, but imho there is no need to apologize or proving his worth.

If you look closely none of us is 'worthy’ and we do not love because someone is 'worthy’ of our love. If only 'worthy’ people were loved, there would be many, many people who would have to go without love. I think one of the wonderful things about Jonsa is that they both have their faults but compliment each other perfectly.

I might be mistaken about your opinion and you were thinking that Jon owes an explanation (not an apology) for bending the knee. In this case I agree. In regard to politics he’d better explain, to Sansa most of all but also to Bran and Arya.

Thanks for the ask or rather the discussion!

blog.name: thedrugdoctor
blog.title: millennial pharmacist.
blog.description: I'm much friendlier than my resting bitch face would suggest. Selfies are here. Ask me about my 4 cats. I love pharmacy, Harry Potter, ASOIAF, The Dark Tower, Final Fantasy, Call Me By Your Name, feminism, men, and women.
